items.title: Gender
items.overview: This module has been prepared to guide capacity building workshops in gender equality and equity. The module has six content units. These include key concepts, stereotypes that perpetuate gender inequity and inequality, conducting a gender analysis using the different frameworks, conducting a participatory appraisal, developing gender aware plans.
items.objectives: The module aims to build the capacity of participants in gender analysis as an important part of the strategy for realisation of gender equity and equality in agencies and communities.
items.approach: By the end of the module, participants will be able to: •	Apply the key concepts and terms in gender equality and equity •	Identify and debunk the key stereotypes that perpetuate gender inequity and inequality •	Conduct gender analyses using the different frameworks •	Conduct a participatory appraisal •	Developing gender aware plans
items.references: 1. Chambers Robert (1999): Whose Reality Counts?: Putting the First. Practical Action Publishing, January 1, 1997: https://www.ids.ac.uk/publications/whose-reality-counts-putting-the-first-last/ 2. March, C, Smyth, I. Mukhopadhyay, M. (1999) A Guide to Gender-Analysis Frameworks, Oxfam, Oxford 3. Monitoring and Evaluation: Some Tools, Methods and Approaches. The International Bank for Reconstructi

questions.question: Which of these statements is True?
questions.hint: This is related to Gender equity and Equality

answers.answer_option: Gender Equality is better than Gender Equity
Gender Equity is better than Gender Equality
Gender Equity means the same thing as Gender Equality
